item.title: Noboru Ando, 89, Mobster and Film Star in Japan, Dies
item.description: Mr. Ando drew on his experience as a gang leader to become a major player in the yakuza genre.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: Narendra Modi of India Meets Pakistani Premier in Surprise Visit
item.description: The Indian prime minister Narendra Modi met with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif amid tentative steps by both nations to improve their historically tense relations.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:credit: Press Information Bureau, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Mr. Sharif, left, greeting Mr. Modi at the airport in Lahore.

item.title: School’s Warnings About Paris Attacker Were Not Passed On
item.description: The government issued an arrest warrant for Bilal Hadfi, but then lost track of him, Belgian officials said after the Nov. 13 attacks, which killed 130 people.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN and MILAN SCHREUER
item.media:description: An undated image of Bilal Hadfi, 20. On Nov. 13, he blew himself up outside the national soccer stadium near Paris.

item.title: Dozens Are Feared Dead After a Landslide in Myanmar
item.description: Local miners say there are as many as 50 people buried in northern Kachin State in the second such episode in just over a month.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Australia Bushfires Strike Popular Tourist Area
item.description: The fires have burned down more than 100 homes, and officials predicted more blazes to come.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.media:description: Residents of evacuated towns at a relief center on Saturday.

item.title: U.N. Sets Syrian Peace Talks as Fighting Complicates Task
item.description: United Nations officials appeared to be signaling that the negotiations would not be affected by gains and losses on the battlefield.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA and ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Women's War: Flawed Justice After a Mob Killed an Afghan Woman
item.description: At first, the trial and convictions in the death of Farkhunda Malikzada seemed a victory in the long struggle to give Afghan women their due in court. But a deeper look suggests otherwise.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Hundreds of people gathered in Kabul to bury Farkhunda. Women carried her coffin, breaking the custom of staying away from funerals.

item.title: Turkish President Erdogan Dissuades Man From Jumping Off Bridge
item.description: The president, known for his sharp rebuttals and rejoinders, used his skills to save a man who contemplated jumping off the Bosporus Bridge.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, right, greeted a man whom he had dissuaded from jumping off the Bosporus Bridge in Istanbul.

item.title: China Says It Will Expel French Journalist
item.description: The reporter, Ursula Gauthier, had written an article criticizing Beijing’s attempt to link the Paris attacks to ethnic violence in China’s northwest.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: In Sweden, a Cash-Free Future Nears
item.description: Few places are tilting toward a cashless future as quickly as Sweden, which has become hooked on the convenience of paying by app and plastic.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:credit: Linus Sundahl-Djerf for The New York Times
item.media:description: The “Kollektomat,” enabling tithing by card, at the Filadelfia church in Stockholm. Only 15 percent of the donations to the church are cash.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: South Sudan: Creation of New States Draws Opposition Protests
item.description: President Salva Kiir dissolved the country’s 10 states and created 28 new ones, a move critics say will threaten the peace deal signed in August.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Quake Rattles Pakistan and Afghanistan
item.description: More than 30 people were injured as houses or walls collapsed in the northwestern Pakistan city of Peshawar.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Leading Cleric Urges Release of Kidnapped Qatari Hunters
item.description: Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani called the kidnapping wrong and said the government must help free the abducted hunters.
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY

item.title: World Briefing: Iran: Relatives Visit a Jailed Reporter
item.description: Jason Rezaian, the Washington Post correspondent who has been incarcerated since July 2014, was permitted an extended visit with his wife and mother.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Powerful Syrian Rebel Leader Reported Killed in Airstrike
item.description: The death of the leader, Zahran Alloush, who commanded the Army of Islam, is a significant blow to the armed opposition in the Syria conflict.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Timothy Peake, British Astronaut, Dials Wrong Number From Space
item.description: Mr. Peake, aboard the International Space Station, took his flub to Twitter, apologizing to “the lady I just called by mistake saying ‘Hello, is this planet Earth?’”
item.dc:creator: JOHN MARKOFF
item.media:description: Timothy Peake, a British astronaut for the European Space Agency, prepared to board a spacecraft bound for the International Space Station on Dec. 15.

item.title: Afghan Province Tucked in Mountains Lies Beyond Reach of Aid and Time
item.description: The difficult terrain of Nuristan Province has brought the region little development over the past 14 years, despite hundreds of billions in foreign aid flowing into the rest of the country.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Suicide Bomber Strikes at Ahmadi Mosque in Bangladesh
item.description: The bomber was the only person killed in the explosion, which wounded three worshipers in the mosque, in a remote northern village.
item.dc:creator: JULFIKAR ALI MANIK

item.title: U.S. Foreign Arms Deals Increased Nearly $10 Billion in 2014
item.description: American weapons sales to other countries rose to $36.2 billion last year, more than half of the global arms trade, a congressional study found.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS FANDOS
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A United States-South Korea joint military exercise in Yeoncheon, northeast of Seoul. South Korea, a key American ally, was the world’s top weapons buyer in 2014, completing $7.8 billion in contracts.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Telling South Sudan’s Tales in a Language Not Its Own
item.description: Stella Gaitano has built a distinguished literary reputation for her writings about conflict and displacement, and she has done so in Arabic, the tongue of the north.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The writer Stella Gaitano in Juba, South Sudan, last year.
